title: Best rearview radars 2025: Eyes on the back of your bike

Best rearview radars 2025: Eyes on the back of your bike

A rearview radar will help you keep tabs on what’s happening behind you, providing alerts on a bike computer when it detects an approaching vehicle – or a faster cyclist.

Originally a Garmin invention, you can now buy rearview radars from a number of other brands. They all work in the same way and are all compatible with a similar range of display devices though, as explained in our buyer’s guide below. Garmin still provides the widest range of rearview radar options and it has also teamed up with Cannondale to include its radar units as part of the SmartSense system fitted to some Cannondale bikes.

Read on for our pick of the best rearview radars available today. Lower down, we’ve got an explainer and buyer’s guide to help you to choose.

The best rearview radars on the market right now

  • Bryton Gardia R300L: RRP €130
  • Garmin Varia RTL515: RRP £170
  • Garmin Varia RCT715: RRP £300
  • iGPSport SR Mini: RRP £100
  • Magicshine SeeMee 508: RRP £130
  • Trek CarBack: RRP £170
  • Wahoo Trackr Radar: RRP £180

Why trust Cyclist‘s advice?

Here at Cyclist, we’re constantly striving to bring you the latest bike tech, as well as the cream of the road bike and gravel bike crop. We’ve tested a fair few of the best rearview radars and for many of us, they’ve become an essential ride accessory that we take on every ride. That means we’re well placed to advise you and understand their benefits and operational quirks.

We’re not paid to review products and don’t accept product placements, so you can be sure that our advice is impartial.

Best rearview radars for cycling

Bryton Gardia R300L

€130 | View offer

The Bryton Gardia R300L includes a rear light that can be set up to work as a brake light. There are four light modes and you can also run radar-only. The claimed maximum runtime is 17 hours in flashing mode and 24 hours radar-only.

There’s a one-piece mount with an integrated strap rather than using an O-ring, so it’s easier to use and there’s no chance of losing it, and the mount comes with adapters for round and aero seat posts. Weight is quoted at 66g.

Garmin Varia RTL515

£170 | View offer

The Garmin Varia RTL515 weighs 71g and includes a rear light with two flashing and two constant modes. Claimed runtime is up to 16 hours in the 65 lumen dayflash mode.

Garmin also sells the RVR315, which is a radar-only unit without a light and the eRTL615 radar taillight, which is designed to be powered by Bosch or Shimano electric bike systems or via a USB A cable.

Garmin Varia RCT715

£300 | View offer

The Garmin Varia RCT715 adds a camera to the light and radar in the unit, recording at up to 1080p/30fps. It loop records footage to the included 16Gb microSD card and will automatically store footage around a detected incident.

The camera reduces maximum battery life to six hours and the unit is also deeper and heavier than the RTL515 at 147g.

iGPSport SR Mini

£100 | View offer

iGPSport sells two rearview radar units, with the SR Mini smaller and newer than the SR30 and, at 30g, lighter than its competitors. It offers seven light modes and includes an accelerometer-actuated braking light mode, as well as ambient light sensing which turns the rear light on when it gets dark or you ride through a tunnel.

The device can be set to automatically power down when a linked iGPSport computer is switched off or when you stop moving. On group rides it can be set so that all riders’ units flash in sync. Claimed battery life is up to 11 hours with radar and light operating and 20 hours for radar-only.

Magicshine SeeMee 508

£130 | View offer

Also sold in some markets branded as a Magene, the SeeMee 508 has a pebble-like shape with smooth curves and rounded edges. It offers five lighting modes from its multiple LED ring, as well as radar-only. Runtime is up to 12 hours or 16 radar-only.

It’s another option with an accelerometer-activated brake mode and can be configured via the Magicshine app.

Trek CarBack

£170 | View offer

Trek’s rearview radar weighs 87g, but is a little smaller than many competitors and can be used with its Blendr accessory mounts.

There are four light modes with up to 90 lumen output and claimed battery life of up to 12 hours, with a series of in-built LEDs to indicate battery level. There’s no brake light mode and no change in intensity when a vehicle is overtaking though and the recessed light reduces side-on visibility.

Wahoo Trackr Radar

£180 | View offer

Wahoo includes two LEDs, one at the top of the unit and one lower down in its Trackr Radar. There’s also an accelerometer, so it can work as a brake light and it will change flash pattern as a car approaches.

There’s a built-in battery extender mode that lowers light output when no car is detected, which Wahoo claims results in a runtime of up to 20 hours. Claimed weight is 99g.

Rearview radars: what to look for

A rearview radar is a useful addition to your cycling armoury, to add a metaphorical extra pair of eyes keeping tabs on what’s happening behind you. It’s particularly handy when you’re riding fast or descending when wind noise can make it hard to hear and you are likely to be concentrating on what’s ahead.

It’s no substitute for situational awareness when riding though. It’s important to keep your own eyes and ears open and not to rely on your rearview radar, particularly if turning across traffic or making other moves out into the road.

Detection range

Rearview radar vendors generally quote a detection range of around 140m. In my experience, on a straight road it’s usually significantly greater than this though.

But on winding roads, vehicles may disappear then reappear from the screen as they become hidden by a bend and re-emerge into view.

Rearview radars have quite a wide detection angle, so you may get alerts for vehicles travelling parallel to you, for example when you’re on a bike path.

If you’ve made a turn onto a side road, you may still be alerted to vehicles continuing on the road you’ve turned off too. Conversely, your radar may not always alert you if a following vehicle has also made the turn.

Size, attachment, weight and more

Almost all rearview radars have a similar format, with an elongated shell that houses the radar in the bottom portion and usually has a rear light in the top of the unit. They’re attached to the bike with a mount, from which they can be removed, usually with a quarter turn.

The mount itself is typically attached to the bike’s seatpost with an integrated rubber strap or separate O-ring. It will be designed to angle the radar unit more-or-less horizontally rearward, which is required for the radar to work effectively. There may be multiple adapters to suit different shaped seatposts.

Most rearview radars are relatively low in weight, but the inclusion of a camera will result in a heavier unit.

In many cases, the taillight can be configured via its companion app to change its lighting or flash pattern when it detects a vehicle behind, which is designed to increase awareness from the approaching driver. Some include an accelerometer and can function as a brake light too.

If you’re riding on wet roads, the radar unit is in the line of fire for wheelspray. That shouldn’t stop it from working and most units are IPX7 ingress protected, so water shouldn’t get in.

Battery life

Battery drain can be significant for a rearview radar, particularly if you’ve chosen a lighting pattern that’s battery intensive. You’ll usually get an alert when the battery is running low, so that you can choose to switch to a lower drain light pattern or to switch the taillight off altogether. If you want extra-long runtime, you can often choose to run the radar without the light.

Head units will usually display an icon to show that there’s a radar connected, so keep an eye on this to make sure that you’re still receiving alerts if your radar’s battery is about to expire.

Connectivity and receiving devices

A rearview radar will detect vehicles. But it needs a display device to alert you that it’s identified something, to which it will transmit data via Bluetooth and usually also ANT+.

That’s usually a cycling computer, which will typically have native display functionality, with a visual and/or audible alert and a bar which appears on one side of the screen with moving icons to indicate the number of vehicles and where they are in relation to you. You may get a different alert for fast-approaching vehicles.

Once a vehicle has passed, you usually get an all-clear alert and the sidebar may disappear from your cycling computer’s screen.

You may also be able to use a rearview radar brand’s app on a smartphone as a display device, with a similar display which shows detected vehicles and their proximity.

Some cycling watches can also link up to a rearview radar; you can download a widget for many Garmin smartwatches which gives you alerts and a proximity display.

A final option is a dedicated head unit that attaches to your handlebars. Garmin used to make one, but this appears to have been discontinued and there are not currently any alternatives sold.

False positives/negatives

I’ve ridden with a few different rearview radars and in general they’re a useful adjunct to situational awareness when riding. It’s particularly helpful to know how close an approaching vehicle is, so you’re less likely to be surprised when it overtakes, especially if it’s a close pass merchant who isn’t going to slow down because the road is narrow or there’s an oncoming vehicle.

As mentioned above, the rearview radar can also be useful if you’re riding fast and may not be able to hear a vehicle behind or look around to see where it is.

There are a few disadvantages to be aware of though.

A rearview radar detects the speed differential between the approaching vehicle and you. If the vehicle is travelling at the same speed, it won’t be detected. So a vehicle that slows down and follows you, waiting to overtake, will disappear from your alert screen. It probably won’t be making much noise either, so make sure to look behind to keep tabs on it.

Multiple vehicles may not all be detected either, even if in most cases you’ll get a dot on your screen for each one. So don’t assume it’s all clear once one vehicle has passed; there may still be more behind you still.

In some cases, a rearview radar can warn you of an approaching vehicle when there’s none there. This seems to happen most frequently when it’s windy, probably triggered by tree branches waving. You’ll usually get an alert that disappears quickly without progressing.

False positives are less of a worry than false negatives. Some units seem to be more prone to these than others. Don’t rely on your radar alone, but use your ears and, as emphasised above, always look behind you before initiating a turn across traffic or other manoeuvre.
